problem.tex: Given a Mobius transformation $f(z)=\frac{az+b}{cz+d}$ give necessary and sufficient conditions on $a,b,c,d$ so that $f$ takes $R=\{z:\Re(z)>0\}$ to $L=\{z:\Re(z)<0\}$.

solution.tex: Fix the Mobius transformation $M$, \[M(z)=\frac{z-1}{z+1}\] which takes \[0\mapsto-1\] \[i\mapsto i\] \[\infty\mapsto1.\] That is, $M(R)=\mathbb{D}$. Note that $M$ also takes $\mathbb{D}$ to $L$ because \[M(1)=0\] \[M(i)=i\] \[M(-1)=\infty.\] If we can classify all Mobius transformations which fix the unit disc then precomposing and postcomposing with $M$ gives all possibilities for $f$. We know that automorphisms of the disc take the form \[\frac{\alpha z+\beta}{\overline\beta z+\overline\alpha}\] where $\alpha,\beta$ are complex numbers with $|\alpha|^2-|\beta|^2=1$. Precomposing with $M$ gives \[\frac{\alpha\frac{z-1}{z+1}+\beta}{\overline\beta\frac{z-1}{z+1}+\overline\alpha}=\frac{\alpha(z-1)+\beta(z+1)}{\overline\beta(z-1)+\overline\alpha(z+1)}=\frac{(\alpha+\beta)z+\beta-\alpha}{\overline{(\alpha+\beta)}z+\overline{(\alpha-\beta)}}.\] Postcomposing with $M$ gives \[\frac{\frac{(\alpha+\beta)z+\beta-\alpha}{\overline{(\alpha+\beta)}z+\overline{(\alpha-\beta)}}-1}{\frac{(\alpha+\beta)z+\beta-\alpha}{\overline{(\alpha+\beta)}z+\overline{(\alpha-\beta)}}+1}=\frac{\frac{(\alpha+\beta)z+\beta-\alpha}{\overline{(\alpha+\beta)}z+\overline{(\alpha-\beta)}}-\frac{\overline{(\alpha+\beta)}z+\overline{(\alpha-\beta)}}{\overline{(\alpha+\beta)}z+\overline{(\alpha-\beta)}}}{\frac{(\alpha+\beta)z+\beta-\alpha}{\overline{(\alpha+\beta)}z+\overline{(\alpha-\beta)}}+\frac{\overline{(\alpha+\beta)}z+\overline{(\alpha-\beta)}}{\overline{(\alpha+\beta)}z+\overline{(\alpha-\beta)}}}\] \[=\frac{(\alpha+\beta)z+(\beta-\alpha)-(\overline{\alpha+\beta})z+(\overline{\beta-\alpha})}{(\alpha+\beta)z+(\beta-\alpha)+(\overline{\alpha+\beta})z-(\overline{\beta-\alpha})}.\] We can multiply top and bottom by 2 and set this equal to $f$ to obtain \[a=i\Im(\alpha+\beta)\] \[b=\Re(\beta-\alpha)\] \[c=\Re(\alpha+\beta)\] \[d=i\Im(\beta-\alpha).\] These are necessary and sufficient conditions, though they can probably be simplified to a nicer form.
